definitions: deceive or cheat someone into believing something that is not true
examples: Don't let that salesman gull you into buying unnecessary insurance
She gulled her little brother into doing her chores

definitions: fasten or seal something using a sticky substance like glue or gum
work the jaws and teeth on something without actually eating it
examples: She carefully gummed the envelope shut before mailing it
He gummed the poster to the wall with adhesive
The baby likes to gum on soft toys during teething
Without his dentures, grandpa could only gum his food

definitions: flow out suddenly and forcefully in large amounts like water or liquid
express excessive enthusiasm or emotion in an unrestrained way about something
examples: Water gushed from the broken pipe flooding the basement
Blood gushed from the wound before the doctor could stop it
She gushed about her new boyfriend to anyone who would listen
The critics gushed over the artist's latest exhibition

definitions: flow or cause to flow in small streams through channels or grooves
burn weakly and unsteadily with a flickering flame before going out
examples: Rain water guttered down the street toward the storm drain
Melted wax guttered along the side of the candle
The candle flame guttered in the wind before dying completely
The fire guttered low as the logs burned to ash

definitions: cut or chop something with rough heavy blows using a tool
break into a computer system or network without permission to access data
manage to deal with or tolerate a difficult situation
examples: He hacked through the thick jungle vines with his machete
She hacked the overgrown branches away from the window
Criminals hacked into the bank's database and stole customer information
She learned to hack computers to test security systems
I can't hack another day of this terrible weather
He couldn't hack the pressure of being a surgeon

definitions: call out to someone to attract their attention or greet them
fall from clouds as small balls of ice during storms
come from or have as one's place of origin or home
examples: She hailed a taxi on the busy downtown street
The doorman hailed us as we entered the hotel
It began to hail during the thunderstorm damaging car windshields
The weather forecast says it will hail this afternoon
She hails from a small farming town in Nebraska
The new chef hails from Paris bringing French cuisine

definitions: honor as holy or make sacred through religious ceremony or reverence
examples: The priest hallowed the ground before building the new church
They hallowed their ancestors' memory with annual ceremonies

definitions: come to a stop or discontinue movement or progress suddenly
cause something or someone to stop moving or continuing an activity
examples: The train halted at the station to let passengers board
The soldiers halted when they heard the commander's whistle
Police halted traffic to allow the parade to pass through
The judge halted the trial until new evidence could be examined

definitions: divide something into two equal parts or reduce by fifty percent
examples: She halved the apple to share with her sister
The company halved its workforce during the economic downturn

definitions: act in an exaggerated theatrical manner to get attention or laughs
examples: The actor hammed it up for the camera during the comedy scene
Stop hamming around and deliver your lines naturally

definitions: prevent someone or something from moving or progressing freely and easily
examples: Bad weather hampered the rescue efforts in the mountains
His injury hampered his ability to compete in the race

definitions: severely limit or destroy the effectiveness of someone or something
examples: Budget cuts hamstrung the research department's important projects
The new regulations hamstring small businesses trying to compete

definitions: place someone or something at a disadvantage making success more difficult
examples: His lack of experience handicapped him in the job interview
Poor internet connection handicaps students trying to learn online

definitions: subject someone to aggressive pressure or intimidation repeatedly over time
examples: The debt collectors harassed him with constant phone calls
Bullies harassed the new student until teachers intervened

definitions: provide refuge or shelter to someone especially when they are in danger
maintain thoughts or feelings in one's mind over a period of time
examples: The family harboured refugees fleeing from the war zone
She was accused of harbouring criminals in her basement
He harboured resentment toward his brother for years
She still harbours hopes of becoming a professional dancer

definitions: make or become firm solid or rigid through cooling drying or setting
make or become less sympathetic gentle or responsive to emotions
examples: Leave the clay to harden in the sun before painting
The cement will harden within twenty-four hours
Years of disappointment hardened her heart against love
War experiences hardened the young soldiers quickly

definitions: listen carefully or pay close attention to something being said
examples: Hark to the sound of church bells in the distance
The teacher told students to hark to her instructions

definitions: bring different elements into agreement or make them work well together
add notes to a melody to create pleasing musical combinations
examples: The new policy harmonises with our company's environmental goals
We need to harmonise our schedules to work on this project
The choir harmonised beautifully during the Christmas concert
She harmonised with the lead singer on the chorus

definitions: bring different elements into agreement or make them work well together
add notes to a melody to create pleasing musical combinations
examples: The committee worked to harmonize conflicting regulations
The interior designer harmonized all the colors in the room
The backup singers harmonized perfectly with the lead vocalist
Can you harmonize with me on this song

definitions: talk or write persistently and tediously about a particular topic
examples: She always harps on about her health problems
Stop harping on my mistakes and help me improve

definitions: spear or strike something especially a large sea animal with a harpoon
examples: The whaler harpooned the whale from the ship's deck
Fishermen harpooned the giant tuna after hours of pursuit

definitions: cause someone to feel extremely distressed upset or tormented emotionally
examples: The documentary's images of war harrowed viewers deeply
Memories of the accident still harrow him at night

definitions: persistently carry out attacks on an enemy or harass someone repeatedly
examples: The guerrillas harried the enemy troops with surprise attacks
Reporters harried the celebrity wherever she went

definitions: gather crops from fields when they are ripe and ready
collect or obtain something as a consequence of actions or efforts
examples: Farmers harvest wheat in late summer when it turns golden
We harvested tomatoes from our garden all season long
The company harvested valuable data from customer surveys
She harvested praise for her outstanding performance

definitions: chop food into small pieces and mix together often for cooking
discuss something thoroughly to reach an agreement or solution
examples: Hash the potatoes and onions together for breakfast
The chef hashed leftover meat with vegetables
Let's hash out the details of the contract tomorrow
They hashed over the problem until finding a solution

definitions: harass pester or create difficulties for someone repeatedly
examples: Don't hassle me about homework while I'm trying to relax
The security guards hassled teenagers hanging around the mall

definitions: move quickly or hurry in doing something to save time
cause something to happen sooner or someone to act more quickly
examples: She hastened to catch the last train home
We must hasten if we want to arrive before dark
The medicine hastened his recovery from the illness
Bad weather hastened our departure from the campsite

definitions: emerge from an egg by breaking through the shell or cause this to happen
devise or create a plan or idea especially in secret
examples: Baby birds hatch after two weeks of incubation
The farmer uses an incubator to hatch chicken eggs
They hatched a plan to surprise their parents on their anniversary
The criminals hatched a scheme to rob the bank

definitions: pull or drag something heavy with great effort over a distance
examples: Workers hauled heavy equipment up the mountain for construction
She hauled her suitcase up three flights of stairs

definitions: manifest as a ghost or spirit in a particular place regularly
continually trouble or preoccupy someone's mind with unpleasant memories
examples: Legend says her ghost haunts the old mansion at night
Spirits are said to haunt the abandoned hospital
Memories of the war still haunt him decades later
The mistake he made continues to haunt his career

definitions: sell goods by calling out in the street or going door to door
examples: Street vendors hawk their wares to passing tourists
He hawks newspapers at the busy train station

definitions: put something at risk or venture to do something dangerous
examples: I wouldn't hazard my reputation on such a risky venture
She hazarded a guess about the test results

definitions: bully or harass newcomers especially as an initiation ritual
examples: Older students hazed freshmen during the first week of college
The fraternity was banned for hazing new members

definitions: hit someone or something forcefully using one's head as a weapon
examples: The angry player headbutted his opponent during the match
The goat headbutted anyone who came too close to its pen

definitions: establish or locate the main offices of an organization in a particular place
examples: The company decided to headquarter its operations in New York
Many tech firms headquarter themselves in Silicon Valley

definitions: put things in a pile carelessly or without any particular order
examples: She heaped dirty clothes in the corner of her room
They heaped praise on the young artist's work

definitions: lift or haul something heavy with great effort and force
rise and fall or move up and down rhythmically
throw something heavy with great effort
examples: Sailors heaved the anchor up from the ocean floor
She heaved the heavy box onto the truck
His chest heaved as he gasped for breath after running
The ship heaved on the stormy seas
He heaved the rock as far as he could
She heaved her bag across the room in frustration

definitions: talk to someone in a bullying domineering way to intimidate them
examples: The boss hectored employees about meeting impossible deadlines
Stop hectoring your little brother and leave him alone

definitions: avoid making a definite statement or commitment about something
protect oneself against financial loss by making counterbalancing transactions
examples: Politicians often hedge when asked about controversial topics
She hedged her answer to avoid offending anyone
Investors hedge their bets by diversifying their portfolios
The company hedged against currency fluctuations

definitions: pay careful attention to and take notice of advice or warning
examples: You should heed your doctor's advice about diet and exercise
Drivers failed to heed warnings about the icy roads

definitions: lift or carry something heavy to test its weight or move it
examples: He hefted the suitcase to see if it was over the weight limit
She hefted the baby into her arms

definitions: make or become more intense greater or higher in degree or amount
examples: The medication heightened her senses making colors seem brighter
Security measures were heightened after the threat

definitions: steal something in a planned robbery especially from an institution
examples: The gang heisted millions from the casino vault
They planned to heist valuable paintings from the museum

definitions: steer a ship or boat by controlling its helm or steering mechanism
examples: The captain helmed the ship through dangerous waters
She learned to helm sailboats during summer vacation

definitions: fold and sew the edge of cloth or clothing to prevent unraveling
surround and restrict someone's movement or ability to act
examples: She hemmed the dress to make it the right length
I need to hem these pants before wearing them
Enemy forces hemmed in the troops on all sides
Don't hem me in with all these rules and restrictions

definitions: suffer heavy bleeding from a ruptured blood vessel or lose rapidly
examples: The patient began to hemorrhage after the accident
The company hemorrhaged money during the economic crisis

definitions: apply reddish-brown dye from henna plant to hair or skin
examples: She hennaed her hair to give it auburn highlights
The bride hennaed her hands with intricate patterns

definitions: announce or signal that something is about to happen or arrive
examples: Spring flowers herald the end of winter's cold
The newspaper heralded the team's victory with bold headlines

definitions: gather and move a group of animals or people in a particular direction
examples: Cowboys herd cattle across the open plains to new pastures
Teachers herded the children into the gymnasium for assembly
